title-group.article-title: Numerical Approximation of Minimum Norm Solutions of $K f = g$ for Special $K$

abstract.p:
Let $K: L_2(Y, \mu) ightarrow L_2(X, 
u)$ be continuous and linear and assume $(Kf)(x) = \int_Y k(x, y)f(y)d\mu(y)$. Define $k_x$ by $k_x(y) = k(x, y)$. Assume $K$ has the property that (a) $k_x \in L_2(Y, \mu)$ for all $x \in X$ and (b) if $Kf = 0 
u$-a.e., then $(Kf)(x) = 0$ for all $x \in X$. For example, if $X = Y = \lbrack0, 1brack, \mu = 
u$ is Lebesgue measure and if $k(x, y)$ satisfies a Lipschitz condition in $x$, then $K$ has the above property. Assume $K$ satisfies this property and $f_0$ is a minimum $L_2$ norm solution of the first-kind integral equation $(Kf)(x) = g(x)$ for all $x \in X$. It is shown that $f_0$ is the $L_2$-norm limit of linear combinations of the $k_{x_i}$'s. It is then shown how to choose constants $c_1,\ldots, c_n$ to minimize $\|f_0 - \sum^n_{j = 1} c_jk_{x_j}\|$ without knowing what $f_0$ is. This paper also contains results on how to choose the $k_{x_j}$'s as well as numerical examples illustrating the theory.
